Poetry Afternoon

03/04/2012

The Poetry Afternoon was a wonderful two hours spent with four very different poets, all of whom connected with the audience in diverse ways.

Image by

By undefined undefined

York Literature Festival 2012, Day 4: Sunday 1 April Venue: Friargate Theatre Time: 3.00-5.30 While the sun shone brightly outside, the dimly lit Friargate Theatre was playing host to four talented poets who had come to showcase their works as part of the York Literature Festival 2012. The Poetry Afternoon was introduced by a warm compere who succeeded in thoroughly involving the audience through his warmth and light hearted humour. Carol Bromley, a Yorkshire based poet told short, sharp anecdotes when introducing her poems, all of which seemed to be based on personal stories which were conveyed in a matter of fact manner; much like a stern teacher at school. Her first poem, In Another Life was about the Canadian Rockies, an area of the world that she had expressed great admiration for. She painted a vivid image through her use of colours in her descriptions and the repetition of 'I would have liked'. Despite the images of nature and freedom that she painted, the poem had a sombre air of underlying regret, which was only accentuated by her monotonous tone of delivery. Bromley went on to channel her poetry through the voice of an imaginary speaker, a technique that proved effective in engaging with the audience and allowing them to become more involved in the poem. Her second poem The Lovers which was based on a Greek painting she had seen, was a keen example of this. In the painting, the couple are draped in shrouds and are thus unable to see one another's faces; she imagines what the woman was thinking or imagining at the time when the painting is set. The poem captures perfectly the feeling of disappointment that one feels when reality does not live up to the dreams that have been fashioned in your imagination. She also used this same technique to a more humorous effect in a poem where she imagined how Wyatt's wife felt when all he brought her back from his travels was a sonnet. The line "Oh well at least its short" was greeted by laughter throughout the packed theatre. Family ties are clearly a huge influence for Bromley, as the rest of her poems were based on her own family. She spoke frankly and poignantly about her brother in law's death whilst introducing the poem Suddenly as a Result of an Accident. The poem was written in the form of a letter to her mother in law, and was extremely moving and emotive. The audience fell silent as Bromley managed to convey the tragedy in a manner that was neither contrived nor melodramatic. The poem beautifully captured the loss and emptiness that is felt whilst in mourning. Bromley continued the theme of mourning in her poem about the dreams she had after her own father's death. In the poem Jonathan she speaks of a certain kind of mourning that many mothers go through when their children leave home, commonly referred to as 'Empty Nest Syndrome.' She spoke of how she left her son (who moved to Australia) at the airport terminal; "fitting term 'terminal building'" she expressed; in a manner that was very honest, a sense that characterised the poem itself. She interspersed these rather sad poems with more humorous ones and funny anecdotes. One that particularly sticks in my mind was Afternoon with Billy. About her grandson; the poem answered the endless list of questions that are often asked by young children and showed perfectly the innocence of the child in contrast with the growing annoyance of the adult who has to answer the questions. The second poet was the young, confident and sarcastic Anthony Dunn. He introduced his first poem in an unorthodox way "you might hate it" he bluntly told the audience, and went on to deliver a short, punchy and angry poem. He also spoke a lot about his travels on trains, repeating "did I mention I travel a lot on trains?" to the audience regularly, which was received with amusement. Many of his poems were based on this subject, adding a sense of rhythm to his reading. The fourth poem he read, which he had written for Her Majesty... Carol Ann Duffy seemed to have a pronounced effect on the audience. 18 was predominantly about when he was eighteen, having just finished his A levels and the poem was included lists of names throughout, which gave it a very nostalgic feeling. The poem began in a light hearted way about smoking and drinking with friends but quickly moved on to a more poignant message. The line "we had exhausted everything that burnt bright and quick" especially conveyed the message of the loss of youth he was trying to create. Whilst most of his readings were very light hearted and short, there was one point when, seemingly out of the blue, he spoke more directly about personal tragedy. He told his audience about how he and his wife had failed to conceive, and how on one awful occasion the IVF had failed. The poem Invitro was a harrowing account when they found this was the case, which happened whilst they were at a wedding. The poem was particularly powerful due to Dunn's juxtaposing the happy wedding scenes and their devastating discovery, to great effect. Abi Curtis delivered her poems, that mainly centred around the theme of animals, in a slow and methodical way. Her poem Rays was well received by the audience and was, in parts, witty, and in others deep. "Huge fish with the faces of people we once knew; Geography teachers" was one such witty comment that was greeted by laughter rippling throughout the theatre. The poem then moved on to "flat rolling children who believe they move the oceans" which was a very insightful way of portraying the egotistical view of the world that children often hold. Curtis, in contrast to the other poets, allowed her poetry to do most of the talking and kept her anecdotes to an absolute minimum. One of the few stories she did indulge in was growing up in a purpose built town in Essex and the poem that followed, Purpose Built Town, had a very haunting an Utopian-esc air to it. This was made clear through her use of adjectives and the dramatic account of a boy drowning in marsh land. The final poet, and by far the most intriguing, was Jack Mapanje. Having been detained in Malawi as a prisoner for his anti-establishment poetry, he moved to York 21 years ago where he has since resided. He spoke of how the book he has recently published about his time in a Malawian prison was him "putting the story to rest" and how he now feels he can write poetry about whatever he chooses. The theme that ran through all of his readings was travelling. He spoke, in a deep, grave tone about how when one is exiled, one's whole life becomes about travelling. His poems were amusing and all in some way autobiographical which made them enthralling to listen to. His first poem in particular, The Taxis of North Yorkshire was particularly funny and seemed to relate directly to experiences that everyone has had regarding taxi drivers "you trust the taxi driver with your life" when he spoke of how you tell taxi drivers your whole life story. Poetry Afternoon was a wonderful 2 hours spent with four very different poets, each of which had unique qualities and connected with the audience in completely diverse ways.
